string-array.name: presidents_facts
string-array.item: He wore denture made of hippopotamus ivory, bone, animal and human teeth, lead, brass screws and gold wire.
John Adams visited Shakespeare`s home in Stratford-upon-Avon with Thomas Jefferson and chipped off a piece of one of Shakespeare`s chairs as a souvenir.
Jefferson he invented the swivel chair! He also hated public speaking so much that he only gave two speeches in his presidency, one per term.
Was the smallest president stood at 5`4`` and weighed around 100 pounds.
Due to his penchant for outdated Revolutionary War era dress, Monroe`s nickname was "The Last Cocked Hat."
John Quincy Adams was known for skinny dipping in the Potomac River every morning.
He was involved in an estimated 100 duels, usually because someone said something negative about his wife.
Van Buren holds the title of the first president to be born in the U.S.
Harrison gave the longest inauguration speech ever (8,445 words over 90 minutes) on a wet, cold day in 1841 and died 33 days into his presidency.
Was the first vicepresident who become president, paving the way for the 25th Amendment, which made the line of succession official.
Every party has a pooper and that pooper was Polk. He banned booze, card playing and dancing from the White House.
Snacked on a bunch of cherries and washed it all down with iced milk (ew). Bacteria was present in either the cherries or the milk, leading to his death a few days later.
Fillmore married his schoolteacher (oo la la!).
Was arrested for running over an old lady with his horse.
Buchanan holds the record of being the only bachelor to be president, although he may not have been truly single.
He was a bartender and also a really good wrestler. He won all but one of approximately 300 matches.
The first president to be impeached, Johnson didn`t have an easy time in childhood either.
Grant could not stand the sight of blood, which is ironic considering his Civil War history.
The victor of one of the most disputed elections ever; he lost the popular vote by 250,000, but eked out an electoral college win by a single vote.
Garfield was ambidextrous and could write in Greek with one hand and in Latin with the other at the same time!
Sold off 24 wagon loads of historical relics, including a pair of Lincoln`s pants and one of John Quincy Adams` hats to pay for redecorating the White House.
Married at the White House the youngest First Lady ever (age 21).
He was the first president to have electricity in the White House and was very scared of being electrocuted.
Cleveland is the only president to hold the office for two non-consecutive terms.
McKinley considered carnations his good luck charm and wore them everywhere.
A toy maker produced "Teddy Bears" in his honor, after news got out that Roosevelt refused to shoot a bear cub on a hunting trip.
Taft is most known for his waist line and supposedly getting stuck in a bathtub (historians say this didn`t really happen).
He relied heavily on his wife Edith Bolling Galt, a descendant of Pocahontas (!!!), for help, leading to her nickname as the "Presidentress."

Harding messed around with a woman named Nan Britton, who wrote a book called "The President`s Daughter" about how her daughter was Harding`s. In 2005, thanks to DNA testing, it was proven that he was in fact the baby daddy.
Coolidge had two pet raccoons named Reuben and Rebecca, who would sometimes run around the White House.
Hoover and his wife lived in China for a time and would speak Mandarin in the White House when they wanted to have a private conversation.
FDR was really afraid of the number 13 and refused to have dinner with that number of people or leave for a trip on the 13th of any month.
He met his wife, Bess, in Sunday school when he was six.
Ike changed the name the presidential retreat in Maryland from Shangri-la to Camp David.
The youngest person—and first Catholic—to be elected to the U.S. presidency.
Johnson initiated the "Great Society" social service programs; signed the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the Voting Rights Act of 1965 into law.
Nixon loved to bowl so much that he had a one-lane alley put in the basement of the White House.
Two different assassins tried to take Ford`s life within over a span of 17 days. Both were women.
Carter appeared in an unlikely publication: Playboy.
Reagan regularly consulted with an astrologer, Joan Quigley, before making decisions and scheduling big events.
Bush inspired a Japanese word, "Bushusuru," which means "to do the Bush thing." (Vomiting in public, as Bush did all over the Japanese Prime Minister in 1992).
Bill has two Grammys (one for Best Spoken Word Album and another for Best Spoken Word Album for Children).
W. was his high school`s head cheerleader.
In high school, he used to be called "O'Bomber" for his basketball skills.
